ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Foundations of liberalism, discussing its history, post-French Revolution / American Revolution liberalism, relation to Christianity, challenges from the Right and the Left, progressivism, Cold War liberalism, neoliberalism, Rawls, Golden 90s, 9/11, Obama, Trump, Socialism, Intersectionality, Populism, Post-liberalism, Illiberalism, Crisis?, Technology
It really helped me reckon with the state of not just liberalism but also America in the world today.
Learned a lot about liberalism, the history and present state of it. Very intellectual

I thought I knew what liberalism was before taking this class, but it turns out I didn't. I have a much better understanding of it now, and its faults from the perspective of the left and of the right.

First half: a discussion of liberal political philosophy and its opponents. 
Second half: a discussion of current events and their connection to liberalism.
Modern reactions to liberalism, history of liberalism in America, and left and right critiques of liberalism basic overview.

I learned the different histories of liberalism and how to better take history and apply to the modern day. I also learned how to better read and understand different political and philosophical texts, and draw less than intuitive connections between them.
You will gain a much deeper understanding about the debates underlying a lot of modern politics

I developed the ability to think theoretically about contemporary political phenomena and the way they relate to political history. My writing ability was improved greatly by my TF, Charles, and I was able to see different insights into liberalism.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Covers a wide range of intellectual history across 300+ years and weaves together different writers from across time and space very well. The discussion section is fantastic and vibrant. The exams are just three papers (~1,500-2,000 words) plus section participation. Plus very short weekly assignments for sections (like response paragraphs).

Weaknesses: The lecture is mostly random professorial commentary on the topics. After a few weeks, you realize that the lecture is, for all intents and purposes, just for fun. You don't need to go to any lectures to participate fully in the discussion section and write all the papers.
The real strength of this course was my TF Charlie Troup. And its weakness, if any, was its lack of structure in lecture.
The biggest weakness is a lack of student engagement. Most of the lectures were listening to the panel and a few mins of questions after. Some more engagement with students would have been better

The lecture format with discussion among the three instructors was great. I enjoyed hearing them respond directly to one another (and jab at each other from time to time). It made for lots of interesting and funny moments. I think one thing that could be improved is bridging the gap between theory and current events. I'm partial to theory, so I would have liked to see more of it in the latter parts of the course.

Content is interesting and professors are entertaining. But it's not a traditional class. Lectures and essays aren't really connected. Lectures and sections won't cover all the readings. Take the class if you're interested in the readings and will find the Douthat/Moyn disagreements in lecture entertaining.

Lots of variation in the readings and very thoughtfully curated syllabus. The lectures are less helpful and the sound was muffled for a lot of it. 3 professors lecturing sort of made topic unclear for each day it went on.

The strength of this course is the unconventional format. The three professors essentially doing an IRL podcast was interesting, with their banter or answer to a question often being more insightful than the mini-lecture at the beginning. All of them are really brilliant and great to listen to. While their analysis and teaching were great, I think they were too ambitious when it came to the syllabus. They often never touched all of the readings for one particular class during their discussion, preferring to go deeper on one small point. This made the overall narrative of the class very unclear, as each meeting felt like its own dive into one particular idea on one particular reading. The course would be much better if the syllabus and scope of the class were smaller, tackling the micro-issues the professors would be talking about anyways.

The strength was the section for this course  truly excellent and helped me to improve as a writer.

The lectures were interesting, and each professor is an interesting thinker, but the lectures were redundant and the readings were not always inspiring. The class should be more about putting the three views in conversation with ancient political theory; instead it often felt like the three professors (Douthat and Moyn in particular) were just repeatedly saying their views and never conceding.
Syllabus was great at the beginning (the theory seemed apt), but really lost its way over the course of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I recommend it if you're interested in the intellectual history of liberalism, and critics of liberalism. The discussion section is fantastic. I had fewer than eight students in mine and all of them and the TF were truly fantastic (top 10% of discussion sections at Yale probably). The course is very similar to DS (except only three papers during the semester), so you'll do very well if you were in DS. Even if you weren't, as long as you go to office hours with the TF to review your paper outline and you can handle a few ~loquacious~ people in section, you'll do great.
Yes, merely because of the possibility of getting Charlie as your TF!
Yes I would, it was great to learn about these concepts.
Yes, if you're interested in this sort of thing.

Two things to know about the class:
1. The three professor format means that the lectures are almost like podcasts, with the profs sort of just talking about the stuff that they find interesting. If you like this kind of thing, as I do, take the class, but if you don't then probably don't.
2. The class, to my disappointment, was more about political philosophy than current events. There is some current events, but it's mostly connected to the "what challenges to liberalism exist?" question.
Recommend for basic intro to western liberalism.

I would recommend this class to anyone interested in the history of political ideology. Having the experience of listening to the professors is worth it, even if the curriculum itself is pretty disorganized.
YES! This is one of my favorite classes I've taken at yale.

Yes, if they are interested in political theory and contemporary politics or journalism. But be prepared to encounter similar ideas repeatedly  it can be redundant often. The writing improvement was strong, but the reading and lectures were often trite.
No. Too disorganized and lots of reading we never really got to discuss. Section was great though.
